title: Malawi: Decent and Affordable Housing Program Rolled Out in Mulanje
text:
Rwanda: The Price Paid in Kigali to Keep the City's Image Pristine By Nellie Kanyemba 
Mulanje — The Decent and Affordable Housing (Cement and Iron Sheets) Program has been rolled out in Mulanje district. 
The program is aimed at assisting poor people in rural areas by providing them with subsidized cement, iron sheets and other building materials to help them construct or improve their houses. 
Speaking during the rolling out event in Mulanje, Minister of Lands, Housing and Urban Development Atupele Muluzi said it was government's wish to ensure that vulnerable and low income households no longer live in dilapidated houses. 
Said Muluzi: "Through this program 80 households per constituency are going to benefit every year and five of these will be constructed freely for five chosen most vulnerable households. 
"This means by the end of five years 400 households are going to have good houses which is very exciting to note",he explained. 
On local level the program will be initiated by local councils who will also be collecting payments for the subsidized materials half down the initial price to be paid back within 36 months. 
Also speaking, Minister of Local Government and Rural Development Kondwani Nankhumwa said since his ministry is the one piloting the program locally, he will ensure that things are being done in a transparent manner to make sure intended beneficiaries benefit from the program. 
One of the beneficiaries Esnarth Chirambo who is a widow from Ng'oma Village, TA Chikumbu in the district expressed her heartfelt gratitude for being chosen saying a burden has been lifted off her shoulders as she was failing to construct herself a good house for herself and her three children. 
About 5440 households across the country are to benefit from the 7 billion Malawi Kwacha program which was approved by parliament in 2014. Malawi
